trustZone.name: Private Secured
trustZone.desc: A secured zone within a trusted private zone

classification.name: Personally Identifiable Information
classification.desc: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person ('Data Subject'); an identifiable person is one who can be identified, directly or indirectly, in particular by reference to an identification number or to one or more factors specific to his physical, physiological, mental, economic, cultural or social identity.

asset.name: Personally Identifiable Information
asset.desc: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person ('Data Subject') an identifiable person is one who can be identified, directly or indirectly, in particular by reference to an identification number or to one or more factors specific to his physical, physiological, mental, economic, cultural or social identity.

classification.name: Personally Identifiable Information
classification.desc: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person ('Data Subject'); an identifiable person is one who can be identified, directly or indirectly, in particular by reference to an identification number or to one or more factors specific to his physical, physiological, mental, economic, cultural or social identity.

weakness.name: Cross Site Request Forgery
weakness.desc:
The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. 
 
When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

weakness.name: Insufficient Verification of Data Authenticity
weakness.desc: The software does not sufficiently verify the origin or authenticity of data, in a way that causes it to accept invalid data.

weakness.name: Sensitive authentication data is stored on the system
weakness.desc: Sensitive authentication data comprises full track data, the card validation code or value, and PIN data. The storage of sensitive authentication data after authorization is prohibited! This data is very valuable to malicious individuals as it allows them to generate counterfeit payment cards and create fraudulent transactions. Entities that issue payment cards or that perform or support issuing services will often create and control sensitive authentication data as part of the issuing function. It is allowable for companies that perform, facilitate, or support issuing services to store sensitive authentication data ONLY IF they have a legitimate business need to store such data. It should be noted that all PCI DSS requirements apply to issuers, and the only exception for issuers and issuer processors is that sensitive authentication data may be retained if there is a legitimate reason to do so. A legitimate reason is one that is necessary for the performance of the function being provided for the issuer and not one of convenience. Any such data must be stored securely and in accordance with all PCI DSS and specific payment brand requirements.

countermeasure.name: Apply authorization checks to segregate and control access to user data
countermeasure.desc:
Applications protecting sensitive or otherwise restricted resources must ensure that only appropriate and authorized users can access the application data. It is important that an application prevent unauthorized users gaining inappropriate access to each other's data. Although user A and user B may both be trusted to access data within the application, they may be only authorized to access different subsets of the protected resources.  E.g. user A should not be able to access user B's personal data by manipulating a request (typical examples are the manipulation of an ID value or other object reference sent in the URL or body of an HTTP request).

It is not sufficient to rely on obscurity, for example obfuscated or secret URLs or filenames. The application must validate each request for protected data against the proven identity of the user. Before providing access to restricted resources the application must:

  • Ensure the user has undergone appropriate authentication (identification and verification, or ID&V). E.g. they must have provided their identity and confirmed this with a password, token, or other verification. Typically this is done by checking the validity of the session token issued after login.
  • Confirm the user is authorized to access the data or resource they are requesting. E.g. their confirmed identify is checked against a server-side access control matrix to determine whether they may access the requested resource.
  • Access controls should be granular and make it possible to issue to individual resources to individual users or roles.

URL and asset based access control is provided by most web-frameworks, and it is preferable to use an established and proven framework.

Object-level authorization checks should be considered in every function that accesses a data source using input from the user.

Remediation:

  • Favor not using an ID that has been sent from the client, but instead use an ID that is stored in the session object when accessing a database record by the record ID.
  • Use an authorization mechanism to check if the logged-in user has access to perform the requested action on the record in every function that uses an input from the client to access a record in the database.
  • Use random and unpredictable values as GUIDs for records' IDs.
  • Write tests to evaluate the authorization mechanism. Do not deploy vulnerable changes that break these tests.

reference.name: OSA AC-01 Access Control Policies and Procedures
OSA SI-04 Information System Monitoring Tools And Techniques
OSA SI-12 Information Output Handling And Retention
OWASP Juice Shop: Broken Access Control

test.steps:
1. Using two different browsers configured with an intercepting proxy:
  2. Login as user A in browser A.
  3. Login as user B in browser B.
  4. For every operation that displays sensitive data belonging to user A:
    1. Perform the operation as user A and view their sensitive data.
    2. Obtain the session ID of user B.
    3. Configure the proxy to intercept.
    4. Perform the operation as user A again, but this time intercept all the requests and replace user A's session ID with that of user B.
    5. Ensure that user A's sensitive data is not visible.

To ensure object-level authorization checks are in place:

  • Map out all locations in the application in which user input is used to reference objects directly. For example, locations where user input is used to access a database row, a file, application page, etc.
  • Modify the value of the parameter used to reference objects to see if the application raises an authorization error.
  • Assess whether it is possible to retrieve objects belonging to other users or otherwise bypass authorization.

countermeasure.name: Avoid storing payment card data in the application or database
countermeasure.desc:
Avoiding the storage of payment card data in the application or database is an important security practice for protecting sensitive customer information. The recommendation is to refrain from storing any payment card data, including credit card numbers, expiration dates, or CVV codes, within the application or its associated database. Rather than saving the data, the application should securely process the payment without retaining the card details.

Storing payment card data amplifies the risk of unauthorized access, data breaches, and potential misuse of sensitive card information. By abstaining from storing card data, the impact of a security breach can be significantly reduced.

Remediation

  • Implement tokenization: Tokenization is a method of substituting sensitive payment card data with unique tokens.
  • Use a payment gateway: Integrate with a reputable payment gateway that handles the payment process securely.
  • Securely transmit data: When transmitting payment card data between your application and external services, ensure that you use secure communication protocols such as HTTPS to encrypt the data in transit.
  • Compliance with PCI DSS: Adhere to the Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS) requirements.
  • Regularly review and update security measures: Stay up to date with the latest security best practices and industry standards.

reference.name: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI-DSS) v4.0

test.steps:
Data Storage Audit:

  • Review the application's database and associated storage systems.
  • Ensure that no payment card data, such as credit card numbers, expiration dates, or CVV codes, are stored.
  • Confirm that any previously stored card data has been removed or encrypted properly.

countermeasure.name: Ensure sensitive data is not revealed through error output messages
countermeasure.desc: Ensure the application does not output error messages or stack traces containing sensitive data that could assist an attacker, including the session id, software/framework versions and personal information.

reference.name: OSA SI-01 System And Information Integrity Policy And Procedures
OSA SI-12 Information Output Handling And Retention

test.steps: Check the application does not output error massages or stack traces containing sensitive data.

countermeasure.name: Implement 3D Secure 2
countermeasure.desc:
3D Secure 2 is a protocol used by credit card companies to provide an additional layer of security for online transactions. Implementing 3D Secure 2 involves implementing a protocol that adds an additional layer of security to the checkout process by requiring the user to provide additional authentication information before completing a transaction.

When a user initiates a transaction, the software tool sends a request to the credit card issuer to verify the user's identity. The credit card issuer then prompts the user to provide additional authentication information, such as a one-time code sent to their mobile phone or email address, or a biometric identifier such as a fingerprint or facial recognition. Once the user provides the additional authentication information, the credit card issuer verifies their identity and sends a response back to the software tool indicating whether the transaction can be completed. This additional layer of security helps to prevent fraudulent activities such as credit card fraud and identity theft.

Remediation

  • Review and update the 3D Secure 2 implementation regularly to ensure it remains effective and up-to-date.
  • Conduct regular audits and assessments of the checkout process to identify any weaknesses or vulnerabilities.
  • Provide clear and concise communication to customers about the 3D Secure 2 process, including how it works and what customers can expect during the checkout process.
  • Ensure that the 3D Secure 2 implementation is user-friendly and does not unduly delay or inconvenience customers during the checkout process.
  • Provide training to personnel on how to assist customers with the 3D Secure 2 process when needed.

test.steps:
1- Initiate a transaction:

  • Initiate a transaction using a valid credit card and ensure that the 3D Secure 2 protocol is triggered by the software tool.

2- Provide additional authentication information:

  • Provide the additional authentication information requested by the credit card issuer, such as a one-time code sent to your mobile phone or email address, or a biometric identifier such as a fingerprint or facial recognition.
  • Ensure that the additional authentication information is verified by the credit card issuer and that the transaction is approved or declined based on the verification result.

3- Verify user experience:

  • Verify that the 3D Secure 2 process is user-friendly and does not unduly delay or inconvenience customers during the checkout process.
  • Ensure that clear and concise communication is provided to customers about the 3D Secure 2 process, including how it works and what customers can expect during the checkout process.

countermeasure.name: Implement application and network rate limiting
countermeasure.desc:
A number of attacks rely on brute-force techniques to send large volumes of requests to enumerate or attempt to exploit flaws in an application, for example, sending common passwords to multiple target accounts within an application. By profiling normal traffic volumes, and applying rate limiting, the application can be built to actively mitigate such attacks. 

  • Connection rate-limiting based on the source IP address can be used to restrict attacks against the authentication or registration systems. Multiple failures (or attempts) from a single IP should result in temporarily blocking or dropping traffic from the source. Note however that some corporate and ISP environments may place multiple valid and discrete clients behind the same IP address, resulting in false-positives.
  • Attackers may use botnets and other IP masking techniques to deliver attacks to avoid IP based rate-limiting. To mitigate this class of attack, Indicators of Compromise should be monitored (for example a higher rate of login failures than usual), and appropriate actions taken. For example, when the application detects active brute-force attacks, a Web Application Firewall (WAF) or other intermediate devices could be used to block attacks sharing a signature from pattern matching or deep packet inspection (e.g. HTTP headers or common passwords across multiple accounts). Similarly, the application could respond by requiring a CAPTCHA, cookie, or Javascript challenge when an attack is detected.

Remediation: 

Implement the mechanisms to lockout accounts: 

  • When the application detects a set number of failure login attempts, the account shall be locked for a certain time period. This period shall be increased as per each new failed attempt up to an hour as maximum.
  • When the application detects an account is locked more times than usual, this account should be disabled (no more than 100 failure attempts). A disabled account should only be restored by an administrator.
  • When the application detects active brute-force attacks, the application shall require a CAPTCHA, cookie, or JavaScript challenge before attempting authentication.
  • Only accept those authentication requests that come from a white list of IP addresses from which the user has been successfully authenticated before.
  • If the user successfully authenticates, the previous failed attempts shall be reset for that user from the same IP address.

For API rate limiting there are several methods that can be applied:

  • Throttling: based on certain rules a request can be slowed down considerably to allow other requests to be served first
  • Request queues: limit the number of request in a given period of time (e.g. five requests per second)
  • Token bucket: commonly used in public APIs, each user has a number of tokens to call the API. After all tokens have been used the user has to wait until the number of tokens are renewed
  • Fixed window: requests that exceed a fixed limit in a period of time will be blocked temporarily
  • Leaky bucket: requests are put in a FIFO queue and will be served accordingly
  • Sliding log: a time-stamped log is used to identify user actions, so the rate limit can be applied for a specified user to avoid more than X actions in a period of time
  • Sliding window: combination of fixed window and sliding log

From a user perspective, implementing timeouts and calling paginated endpoints can reduce the impact of having a very large response that can freeze the system.

reference.name: OSA IA-01 Identification And Authentication Policy And Procedures
OWASP Juice Shop: Broken Access Control

standard.ref: API4:2023-Lack of Resources and Rate Limiting

test.steps:
Use tools like THC-Hydra, OWASP ZAP or Burp Suite to simulate brute force attacks against the login function. 

  • Perform a simulation of the attack against the login function.
  • Verify the function is blocked for your source after n attempts.
  • Verify there is a log alerting function for an unusual amount of failed login attempts, even if they originated from different sources.

countermeasure.name: Implement fraud detection and prevention measures
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing fraud detection and prevention involves implementing a set of rules and procedures that can detect and prevent fraudulent activities during the checkout process. This can include a combination of automated and manual review processes, as well as the use of fraud detection tools and techniques.

Automated fraud detection tools can include algorithms that analyze patterns of behavior, such as the frequency and amount of transactions, to identify potentially fraudulent activities. These tools can also include real-time monitoring and alerts that notify users of suspicious activity and prompt them to take action.

Manual review processes can involve trained personnel who review transactions for signs of fraud, such as unusual shipping addresses or payment methods. These personnel can also use additional tools and techniques, such as identity verification checks and background checks, to further validate transactions.

By implementing fraud detection and prevention, companies can reduce the risk of fraudulent activities such as address tampering, credit card fraud, or identity theft.

Remediation

  • Review and update the fraud detection and prevention measures regularly to ensure they remain effective and up-to-date.
  • Conduct regular audits and assessments of the checkout process to identify any weaknesses or vulnerabilities.
  • Provide training to personnel on how to detect and prevent fraudulent activities during the checkout process.
  • Implement additional security measures, such as two-factor authentication or multi-step verification.
  • Provide clear and concise communication to customers about the fraud detection and prevention measures in place.

reference.name: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI-DSS) v4.0

test.steps:
1- Validate address fields for expected formats:

  • Enter a valid address in the address field and ensure that it is accepted by the software tool.
  • Enter an invalid address in the address field and ensure that it is rejected by the software tool, with an appropriate error message displayed to the user.
  • Enter an address with missing or incomplete information and ensure that the software tool prompts the user to correct the errors before proceeding.

2- Implement fraud detection and prevention measures:

  • Conduct a test transaction with a known fraudulent credit card and ensure that the software tool detects the fraud and prevents the transaction from being completed.
  • Conduct a test transaction with a valid credit card but with an unusual shipping address, and ensure that the software tool flags the transaction for manual review by personnel.
  • Conduct a test transaction with a valid credit card and shipping address, and ensure that the transaction is completed successfully without any issues.

countermeasure.name: Implement Security Logging and Monitoring
countermeasure.desc:
Logging is often neglected by developers when thinking of security considerations. However, proper logging practices can provide the crucial forensics needed to investigate after a breach, and perhaps more importantly, to detect security issues as they happen. Most developers are already familiar with logging for debugging and diagnostic purposes, so it should be easy for them to apply the concept of security logging.

Remediation: 

  • Actions to do:
    • Log all failed authentication attempts, denied access, and input validation errors.
    • Terminate the offending user session to inhibit further attack.
    • Ensure errors returned to the client-side are generic to prevent an attacker enumerating the defenses in place or gaining knowledge about the back-end.
    • Configure a monitoring system to continuously monitor the infrastructure, network, and the API functioning.
    • Use a Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) system to aggregate and manage logs across all components and hosts.
    • Configure custom dashboards and alerts, making it possible to detect and respond to suspicious activity as early as possible.
  • Log considerations:
    • Ensure logged data is appropriately sanitized and encoded to prevent attacks against the logs and subsequent access to them.
    • Logs should be written using a format suited to be consumed by a log management solution, and include enough details to identify the malicious actor.
    • Logs need to be handled as sensitive data, and their integrity should be guaranteed at rest and transit.

reference.name: OWASP Proactive Controls C9: Implement Security Logging and Monitoring

test.steps:
Organizations should perform testing and validation activities periodically to confirm that the organization's logging policies, processes, and procedures are being followed properly both at the infrastructure level and the system level throughout the organization.  Log management audits can identify deficiencies in policies, procedures, technology, and training that can then be addressed.

The most common techniques for testing and validating logging are as follows: 

  • Auditors or others performing testing and validation can review the logging configuration and settings, as well as the system logs, infrastructure logs, and archived logs, for a representative sampling of systems and infrastructure servers to ensure that they comply with policies and procedures.
  • Auditors (or security administrators under the direction of auditors) or others performing testing and validation can create security events on a representative sampling of systems through vulnerability scanning, penetration testing, or routine actions (e.g., logging onto a system remotely), and then ensure that the log data those activities should generate exist and are handled according to the organization's policies and procedures.

Steps:

  1. Confirm all security events (and suspicious activity that may indicate a security event) are appropriately identified in the application.
  2. Confirm security errors are logged with appropriate priority.
  3. Any data logged relating to the event must be carefully sanitized and encoded; by definition the data could be an attack payload and could execute when the logs are viewed outside of the system.
  4. Verify actual logged data.

reference.name: Guide to Computer Security Log Management

countermeasure.name: Implement strict validation checks for shipping addresses
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing strict validation checks for shipping addresses involves implementing a set of rules or criteria that must be met before a shipping address is accepted. This can be done through various means, such as using regular expressions, pattern matching, or database lookups to verify the format and accuracy of the shipping address.

The software tool can also be programmed to flag any discrepancies or errors in the shipping address and prompt the user to correct them before proceeding with the shipping process. Additionally, it can be designed to provide real-time feedback to the user on the accuracy and completeness of the shipping address.

However, it is important to ensure that the validation checks are not so restrictive that they prevent legitimate addresses from being accepted. Therefore, it is important to strike a balance between security and convenience when implementing this countermeasure in a software tool.

Remediation

  • Develop a set of rules or criteria for validating shipping addresses based on industry standards and best practices
  • Implement automated address verification tools that can validate shipping addresses in real-time and flag any discrepancies or errors
  • Regularly review and update the validation rules and procedures to ensure they remain effective and up-to-date
  • Conduct regular audits and assessments of the validation process to identify any weaknesses or vulnerabilities

test.steps:
1. Test the automated address verification tool: Verify that the automated address verification tool is correctly configured and is able to validate shipping addresses in real-time. This can be done by entering a set of valid and invalid addresses and verifying that the tool is able to identify and flag any discrepancies or errors.
  2. Test the manual review process: Verify that users are able to manually review and validate shipping addresses when automated tools are not available or when there are exceptions to the rules. This can be done by providing a set of addresses that require manual review and verifying that the users are able to correctly validate them.
  3. Test the validation rules and procedures: Verify that the validation rules and procedures are effective in preventing shipping address tampering and other fraudulent activities. This can be done by reviewing a sample of shipping addresses that have been processed and verifying that they meet the validation criteria.
  4. Test the audit and assessment program: Verify that regular audits and assessments of the validation process are being conducted. This can be done by reviewing audit reports and assessing the effectiveness of any corrective actions taken.

countermeasure.name: Implement tokenization or encryption techniques to protect sensitive card information
countermeasure.desc:
Implement tokenization or encryption techniques to protect sensitive card information is a security practice used in software systems to safeguard sensitive card information during storage, transmission, and processing. It involves replacing the actual card data with tokens or encrypting the data to prevent unauthorized access and mitigate the risk of data breaches.

Tokenization is a technique where the sensitive card information, such as the credit card number, is substituted with a randomly generated token. The token is then used within the software system for transactional or identification purposes. The actual card data is securely stored in a separate system or environment, known as a tokenization vault.

Encryption, on the other hand, involves converting the sensitive card data into an unreadable format using encryption algorithms. The data is encrypted before it is stored, transmitted, or processed and can only be decrypted using a unique encryption key.

Implementing tokenization or encryption techniques provides multiple layers of protection for sensitive card information. It reduces the risk of exposing card data during storage, transmission, or processing, making it significantly more challenging for attackers to misuse or extract valuable information.

Remediation

  • Assess and Identify Sensitive Card Data: Conduct a thorough assessment to identify the sensitive card data that needs protection within your software system.
  • Determine Appropriate Tokenization or Encryption Methods: Select the most suitable tokenization or encryption methods based on your system's requirements and industry best practices.
  • Implement Tokenization or Encryption Framework: Integrate a reliable tokenization or encryption framework into your software system.
  • Secure Key Management: Ensure proper key management practices for encryption, including secure key storage, rotation, and access controls.
  • Apply Tokenization or Encryption at Appropriate Points: Identify the specific areas within your software system where sensitive card information is stored, transmitted, or processed.
  • Test and Validate Implementation: Conduct thorough testing to verify the effectiveness of the tokenization or encryption implementation.
  • Regularly Review and Update: Continuously monitor and review the tokenization or encryption mechanisms in your software system to ensure they remain robust and up to date.

test.steps:
• Test Data Capture: Simulate the process of capturing card data within the software system. Verify that sensitive card information, such as credit card numbers, expiration dates, and CVV codes, are appropriately masked or replaced with tokens during the data capture process.
  • Test Data Storage: Evaluate the storage mechanism used for sensitive card data. Confirm that the actual card information is not stored in its original form and that tokenized or encrypted data is persisted in the database. Retrieve and examine stored data to ensure that it remains protected.
  • Test Data Transmission: Test the transmission of card data within the software system. Monitor network traffic to verify that sensitive card information is securely transmitted using encryption protocols (e.g., SSL/TLS) and that the decrypted data is never exposed during transit.
  • Test Data Decryption: If encryption is used, validate the decryption process to ensure that the sensitive card data can be correctly decrypted when needed for authorized purposes. Perform decryption tests using test scenarios and validate the accuracy of the decrypted data.
  • Test Integration Points: If the software system interacts with external systems or services, verify that the tokenization or encryption techniques are properly implemented at the integration points. Test data exchange between systems to ensure the seamless integration and protection of sensitive card data throughout the flow.
  • Test User Interface: Assess the user interface components where card data is displayed or entered. Verify that tokenized or masked data is presented to users instead of the actual card information. Test the input validation to ensure that only valid tokens or masked data formats are accepted.
  • Test Tokenization or Encryption Key Management: Evaluate the security measures in place for key management. Test key generation, rotation, and storage processes to ensure the confidentiality and integrity of encryption keys. Validate access controls to protect the keys from unauthorized access.

countermeasure.name: Protect cookies from CSRF
countermeasure.desc:
Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) is a type of attack that occurs when a malicious web site, email, blog, instant message, or program causes a user's web browser to perform an unwanted action on a trusted site when the user is authenticated. A CSRF attack works because browser requests automatically include any credentials associated with the site, such as the user's session cookie, IP address, etc. Therefore, if the user is authenticated to the site, the site cannot distinguish between the forged or legitimate request sent by the victim. A token/identifier that is not accessible to the attacker is needed to mitigate this and would not be sent along (like cookies) with forged requests that the attacker initiates. 


 

Remediation: 

Requiring re-authentication of sensitive functions is an effective way to protect your application against a CSRF, but intrusive to the user experience.

You can also protect cookies from CSRF using at least one or more of the following recommendations: 

  1. CSRF nonces. Use nonces to prevent unauthorized access by providing a secret 'key' (which is valid only once) that must be validated in any sensitive form submission. For maximum security, the nonce is also time sensitive and expires.
  2. Triple or double submit cookie pattern. If maintaining the state for the CSRF token on the server-side is problematic, an alternative defense is to use the double-submit cookie technique. This technique is easy to implement and is stateless. In this technique, a random value is sent in both a cookie and as a request parameter, with the server verifying if the cookie value and request value match. When a user visits (even before authenticating to prevent login CSRF), the site should generate a (cryptographically strong) pseudo random value and set it as a cookie on the user's machine separate from the session identifier. The site then requires that every transaction request include this pseudo-random value as a hidden form value (or other request parameter/header). If both of them match on the server-side, the server accepts it as a legitimate request and if they don't, then rejects the request.
  3. ORIGIN request header checks.There are two steps to this mitigation, both of which rely on examining an HTTP request header value. Firstly, determining the origin the request is coming from (source origin). This can be achieved via Origin and/or referer headers. Secondly, determining the origin the request is going to (target origin). On the server-side verify if both of these match. If they do, we accept the request as legitimate (meaning it's the same origin request) and if they don't, discard the request (meaning that the request originated from a cross-domain). Reliability of these headers comes from the fact they cannot be altered programmatically (using JavaScript in an XSS) as they fall under the forbidden headers list (i.e., only browsers can set them).

reference.name: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) Prevention Cheat Sheet
OSA SI-10 Information Accuracy, Completeness, Validity, And Authenticity

test.steps:
1.- Identify all application components performing sensitive operations. 

2.- Using an intercepting proxy, the Web Developer Console, or other tool; intercept the browser request and server response, and verify a unique strong token is being sent and verified with each request.

3.- Confirm the tokens are passed in a programmatic way resistant to CSRF attack; e.g. in a custom POST field and separate HTTP header.

4.- Attempt to subvert the CSRF controls to ensure they are robust:

  • Change or remove the tokens and confirm the application rejects the request.
  • Attempt to replay the tokens in a subsequent request.
  • Mismatch the tokens in a request.

To modify headers and otherwise modify browser requests, use an intercepting proxy (e.g. OWASP Zap, Burp or Fiddler), or browser extensions such as Cookie Manager or Tamper Data.

countermeasure.name: Reject requests containing unexpected or missing content type headers
countermeasure.desc: Reject requests containing unexpected or missing content type headers with HTTP response status "406 Unacceptable" or "415 Unsupported Media Type".

reference.name: OSA SI-10 Information Accuracy, Completeness, Validity, And Authenticity

test.steps: Check that HTTP requests with non-valid Content-type are rejected.

countermeasure.name: Require additional authentication for sensitive operations / high value transactions
countermeasure.desc:
Having gained access to an account, for example through session hijacking or cross-site scripting, an attack may compromise data and functionality accessible to the victim. This may include elevating privileges or accessing sensitive data and functionality, such as changing passwords, creating accounts, or transferring funds.


 

These critical functions and sensitive data should be further protected from attack using a risk-based authentication model requiring re-authentication via multi-factor authentication, or use of a token to sign transactions or operations.

  • Implement re-authentication on key functions (such as requiring the old password before setting a new one).
  • Use secondary authentication such as a transaction PIN to allow financial transfers.
  • Critical administrative functionality should require multi-factor authentication (such as a hard or soft token).
  • Consider use of signing technologies or tokens that enable the server-side to verify the authenticity of a request and mitigate Man in the Middle (MiTM) or Man in the Browser (MiTB) attacks.

reference.name: OSA IA-01 Identification And Authentication Policy And Procedures

test.steps:
1. Identify critical functionalities of the application. 
  2. Check the risk appetite for those functionalities. 
  3. Validate that re-authentication is required for those functions if deemed necessary.

countermeasure.name: Use a white-list approach to assign values to variables
countermeasure.desc:
All data received from the client-side should be considered tainted and a potential risk, regardless of the source or transport method. Using mass-assignment or auto-binding when accepting values from an untrusted source and mapping them to trusted server side values increases the risk of tainted data being used unsafely.

  • Bind individual values to specific fields, instead of binding whole objects.
  • Use available features of the language or framework that allow specification of white lists of attributes or fields that are allowed to be modified. 
    • For example, applications written with Ruby on Rails can use the attr_accessible (white list) or attr_protected (black list) macros in each class that may be used in mass assignment.

reference.name: OSA SI-10 Information Accuracy, Completeness, Validity, And Authenticity

test.steps:
1. Identify the framework the component is using.
  2. Check if this particular framework provides automatic binding of variables.
  3. Verify if it is disabled or restricted.

countermeasure.name: Utilize a reliable and compliant payment gateway service
countermeasure.desc:
Utilize a reliable and compliant payment gateway service refers to the use of a trusted and compliant payment gateway service to handle the payment processing and ensure the security of sensitive customer information.

This is essential for safeguarding sensitive customer data during payment transactions. By leveraging a reliable and compliant payment gateway service, the application can offload the responsibility of securely handling payment information to a specialized provider. This minimizes the risk of data breaches, fraud, and unauthorized access to customer payment card details.

Remediation

  • Research reputable payment gateway providers: Choose a payment gateway service that is widely recognized, reliable, and has a strong reputation for security
  • Verify PCI DSS compliance: Ensure that the selected payment gateway service is Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS) compliant. PCI DSS sets the industry standards for secure handling of payment card data.
  • Integration and testing: Integrate the payment gateway service into the checkout component of your application following the provider's documentation and guidelines. Conduct thorough testing to verify that payment transactions are securely processed, sensitive data is encrypted, and error handling is properly implemented.
  • Monitor security updates: Stay informed about security updates, patches, and new releases from the payment gateway provider. Keep the integration up to date to benefit from the latest security enhancements.

reference.name: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI-DSS) v4.0

test.steps:
Functional Testing:

  • Initiate test transactions using various payment methods (credit card, debit card, etc.) through the checkout component.
  • Confirm that the payment gateway service securely processes the transactions and returns appropriate responses.
  • Verify that the payment gateway correctly handles different scenarios, such as declined transactions, expired cards, and valid transactions.

Security Testing:

  • Perform security scanning and penetration testing on the checkout component.
  • Verify that sensitive payment data is encrypted and securely transmitted to the payment gateway using industry-standard protocols such as HTTPS.
  • Validate that the payment gateway's integration with your application follows secure coding practices and protects against common vulnerabilities, such as SQL injection or cross-site scripting.

countermeasure.name: Validate all data received
countermeasure.desc:
All data received should be considered tainted and a potential risk, regardless of the source or transport method. For example, while hidden form fields, cookies or other headers may be obfuscated from a user, along with parameters passed in ViewStates or other encapsulated forms. These can be modified by the user on the client-side in memory, or in transit on the network. Similarly, data passed from binary or compiled components can be modified in situ or in transit. Furthermore, encryption only secures the data in transit between the two ends of the encrypted tunnel (one of which is typically controlled by the client); data passing through the link may still be malicious.

As such, all data from the client side must be subjected to strict validation, sanitization, and encoding against expected syntactic and semantic criteria.
  • Define a specification of the data that is expected at each input; both the syntax (e.g. alphanumeric only) and semantics (e.g. a word of between 1 and 25 characters, or a specific list). As an example of business rule logic, "boat" may be syntactically valid because it only contains alphanumeric characters, but it is not valid if the input is only expected to contain colors such as "red" or "blue." 
  • Implement a 'known good' or white-list approach, where only inputs that meet the strict criteria for each input are accepted, and reject, transform, or encapsulate any non-compliant data. 
  • While useful for identifying malicious content, do not rely on looking for specific malformed or attack payloads (blacklists). It is almost impossible to maintain a comprehensive and accurate blacklist due to the complexity and evolving nature of attacks, opportunities to obfuscate payloads, and changes to the code's execution environment. As noted, blacklists can be useful for detecting and logging potential attacks, or determining which inputs are so malformed that they should be rejected outright. 
  • Validate all data received from the client, including values such as HTTP headers and cookie values if these are used as input on the server side, X- headers, and other platform specific data objects passed between the client and server.

reference.name: OSA SI-01 System And Information Integrity Policy And Procedures
OSA SI-10 Information Accuracy, Completeness, Validity, And Authenticity

test.steps:
Identify data input points for the application, for example: 

  • Forms with user input (including hidden fields)
  • API calls
  • HTTP Headers
  • Application states such as ASP Viewstates
  • Serialized Java objects
  • Any data structure received from the client-side
  • For every input, define accepted input (both syntactic and semantic criteria)
  • Where possible, define a white-list of accepted input or characters
  • For each of the inputs, ensure that the data is validated against the defined whitelists (for example with a regular expression) before being processed.

To test data validation:  

  • Review the acceptable input criteria, and build test cases that deviate from it (invalid characters, lengths, ranges etc.).
  • Pass invalid input to the application and review error trapping and handling.
  • Where unexpected exceptions occur, the application may be vulnerable to attack.

A number of tools can be used to aid in testing:

  • Directly from your browser with the Developer Tools.
  • Using a browser extension which allows you to modify the request and responses on the fly (i.e. Tamper Data).
  • Using a proxy which allows you to modify the request and response on the fly (i.e. OWASP ZAP, Burp, Fiddler, etc.).

threat.name: Attackers can enumerate the existence of valid accounts in the system using error/informational messages
threat.desc: If your login page has different error messages for unrecognized usernames and incorrect passwords, an attacker can write a script to submit lengthy lists of common usernames and test the response. With those results, the attacker can then infer which usernames are valid.

threat.name: Attackers gain access to the personal identification number (PIN) or the encrypted PIN block after authorization
threat.desc: If full track data is stored, malicious individuals who obtain that data can use it to reproduce payment cards and complete fraudulent transactions. The purpose of the card validation code is to protect "card-not-present" transactions-Internet or mail order/telephone order (MO/TO) transactions-where the consumer and the card are not present. If this data is stolen, malicious individuals can execute fraudulent Internet and MO/TO transactions. These values should be known only to the card owner or bank that issued the card. If this data is stolen, malicious individuals can execute fraudulent PIN-based debit transactions (for example, ATM withdrawals).

threat.name: An attacker gains access to the software during the shipping process
threat.desc: Shipping address tampering refers to the unauthorized modification of a delivery address during the shipping process. This can occur when a user with malicious intent gains access to the software and manipulates the delivery address for fraudulent purposes. This can result in packages being delivered to unintended locations, causing delays, lost packages, and other issues.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized access to data and/or systems through Injection attacks
threat.desc:
Some of the most common types of injection attacks are SQL injections, cross-site scripting (XSS), code injection, OS command injection, host header injection, and more. A large part of vulnerabilities that exist in web applications can be classified as injection vulnerabilities.

  • Scenario #1: An application uses untrusted data in the construction of the following vulnerable SQL call:

String query = "SELECT * FROM accounts WHERE custID='' request.getParameter("id") + '';

  • Scenario #2: Similarly, an application's blind trust in frameworks may result in queries that are still vulnerable, (e.g. Hibernate Query Language (HQL)):

Query HQLQuery = session.createQuery("FROM accounts WHERE custID=' '+ request.getParameter("id") + "'");

In both cases, the attacker modifies the 'id' parameter value in their browser to send: ' or '1'='1. For example:

http://example.com/app/accountView?id=''or '1'='1

This changes the meaning of both queries to return all the records from the accounts table. More dangerous attacks could modify or delete data, or even invoke stored procedures.

threat.name: An attacker exploits a weakness in the configuration of access controls and is able to bypass the intended protection that these measures guard against and thereby obtain unauthorized access to the application
threat.desc: An Access Control functionality often spans many areas of software depending on the complexity of the access control system. For example, managing access control metadata or building caching for scalability purposes are often additional components in an access control system that need to be built or managed. Vulnerabilities appear when a user is able to successfully request access to something they usually shouldn't have access to. Oftentimes this is found when the authorization is not implemented properly. A typical example would be a certain endpoint on a website that throws a 403 forbidden error which is then bypassed by adding an X-Forwarded-For: "127.0.0.1" header.

threat.name: An attacker crafts malicious web links and distributes them hoping to induce users to click on the link and execute a malicious action
threat.desc:
An attacker crafts malicious web links and distributes them (via web pages, email, etc.), typically in a targeted manner, hoping to induce users to click on the link and execute the malicious action against some third-party application. If successful, the action embedded in the malicious link will be processed and accepted by the targeted application with the users' privilege level.
This type of attack leverages the persistence and implicit trust placed in user session cookies by many web applications today. In such an architecture, once the user authenticates to an application and a session cookie is created on the user's system, all following transactions for that session are authenticated using that cookie including potential actions initiated by an attacker and simply "riding" the existing session cookie.

weakness.name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements in Data Query Logic
weakness.desc:
The application generates a query intended to access or manipulate data in a data store such as a database, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that can modify the intended logic of the query.

Depending on the capabilities of the query language, an attacker could inject additional logic into the query to:

  • Modify the intended selection criteria, thus changing which data entities (e.g., records) are returned, modified, or otherwise manipulated
  • Append additional commands to the query
  • Return more entities than intended
  • Return fewer entities than intended
  • Cause entities to be sorted in an unexpected way

The ability to execute additional commands or change which entities are returned has obvious risks. But when the application logic depends on the order or number of entities, this can also lead to vulnerabilities. For example, if the application query expects to return only one entity that specifies an administrative user, but an attacker can change which entities are returned, this could cause the logic to return information for a regular user and incorrectly assume that the user has administrative privileges.

While this weakness is most commonly associated with SQL injection, there are many other query languages that are also subject to injection attacks, including HTSQL, LDAP, DQL, XQuery, Xpath, and NoSQL languages.

reference.name: CWE-943: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements in Data Query Logic

weakness.name: Input to exported activities, intents or content providers is not validated
weakness.desc:
The product does not validate or incorrectly validates input that can affect the control flow or data flow of a program.
When software does not validate input properly, an attacker is able to craft the input in a form that is not expected by the rest of the application. This will lead to parts of the system receiving unintended input, which may result in altered control flow, arbitrary control of a resource, or arbitrary code execution.

reference.name: CWE-20: Input to exported activities, intents or content providers is not validated

weakness.name: Secrets, API keys and or passwords are included in the source code or online repositories
weakness.desc:
API keys, passwords or secrets included in the source code or in the configuration files can be leaked to users with access to the code. This access can be incidentally granted by publishing the source code on a package-form or an online, public repository.
The unauthorized access to any of those secrets could lead to a compromise of sensitive data or a system.

reference.name: CWE-312: Secrets, API keys and or passwords are included in the source code or online repositories

weakness.name: Use of Insufficiently Random Values
weakness.desc: The software may use insufficiently random numbers or values in a security context that depends on unpredictable numbers.

countermeasure.name: Apply authorization checks to segregate and control access to user data
countermeasure.desc:
Applications protecting sensitive or otherwise restricted resources must ensure that only appropriate and authorized users can access the application data. It is important that an application prevent unauthorized users gaining inappropriate access to each other's data. Although user A and user B may both be trusted to access data within the application, they may be only authorized to access different subsets of the protected resources.  E.g. user A should not be able to access user B's personal data by manipulating a request (typical examples are the manipulation of an ID value or other object reference sent in the URL or body of an HTTP request).

It is not sufficient to rely on obscurity, for example obfuscated or secret URLs or filenames. The application must validate each request for protected data against the proven identity of the user. Before providing access to restricted resources the application must:

  • Ensure the user has undergone appropriate authentication (identification and verification, or ID&V). E.g. they must have provided their identity and confirmed this with a password, token, or other verification. Typically this is done by checking the validity of the session token issued after login.
  • Confirm the user is authorized to access the data or resource they are requesting. E.g. their confirmed identify is checked against a server-side access control matrix to determine whether they may access the requested resource.
  • Access controls should be granular and make it possible to issue to individual resources to individual users or roles.

URL and asset based access control is provided by most web-frameworks, and it is preferable to use an established and proven framework.

Object-level authorization checks should be considered in every function that accesses a data source using input from the user.

Remediation:

  • Favor not using an ID that has been sent from the client, but instead use an ID that is stored in the session object when accessing a database record by the record ID.
  • Use an authorization mechanism to check if the logged-in user has access to perform the requested action on the record in every function that uses an input from the client to access a record in the database.
  • Use random and unpredictable values as GUIDs for records' IDs.
  • Write tests to evaluate the authorization mechanism. Do not deploy vulnerable changes that break these tests.

reference.name: OSA AC-01 Access Control Policies and Procedures
OSA SI-04 Information System Monitoring Tools And Techniques
OSA SI-12 Information Output Handling And Retention
OWASP Juice Shop: Broken Access Control

test.steps:
1. Using two different browsers configured with an intercepting proxy:
  2. Login as user A in browser A.
  3. Login as user B in browser B.
  4. For every operation that displays sensitive data belonging to user A:
    1. Perform the operation as user A and view their sensitive data.
    2. Obtain the session ID of user B.
    3. Configure the proxy to intercept.
    4. Perform the operation as user A again, but this time intercept all the requests and replace user A's session ID with that of user B.
    5. Ensure that user A's sensitive data is not visible.

To ensure object-level authorization checks are in place:

  • Map out all locations in the application in which user input is used to reference objects directly. For example, locations where user input is used to access a database row, a file, application page, etc.
  • Modify the value of the parameter used to reference objects to see if the application raises an authorization error.
  • Assess whether it is possible to retrieve objects belonging to other users or otherwise bypass authorization.

countermeasure.name: Implement strict validation of coupon codes
countermeasure.desc:
Implement strict validation of coupon codes

Rationale:

Implementing a strict validation of coupon codes entails the rigorous enforcement of validation procedures for coupon codes within the E-commerce system. This control involves employing a robust set of rules and checks to verify the legitimacy and accuracy of coupon codes entered by users. Examining factors such as format, expiration dates, usage limitations, and product eligibility, the control ensures that only valid and authorized coupon codes are accepted.

Remediation:

  • Code Structure: Define a standardized format for coupon codes.
  • Generation: Create codes securely using random strings or hashing.
  • Validation Rules: Establish criteria like length, characters, and format.
  • Expiration & Limits: Set expiry dates and usage limits for each code.
  • Product Eligibility: Designate applicable products or categories.
  • Backend Validation: Implement validation logic during checkout.
  • Frontend Feedback: Provide clear user feedback on code validity.
  • Logging: Record code usage for monitoring and auditing.
  • Security: Store codes securely to prevent unauthorized access.
  • Testing: Thoroughly test validation with various scenarios.
  • Documentation: Document rules and procedures for reference.
  • Integration: Seamlessly integrate validation into your system.

Impact:

Implementing strict validation of coupon codes can have an impact on performance, especially if the validation process involves complex rules or requires frequent interactions with databases or external services.

test.steps:
• Valid Coupon Test: Apply various valid coupons to eligible products.
  • Invalid Coupon Test - Format: Enter improperly formatted coupon codes, verify rejection.
  • Invalid Coupon Test - Expiry: Use expired coupons, confirm rejection.
  • Usage Limits Test: Exceed coupon usage limits, verify prevention.
  • Product Eligibility Test: Apply coupons to ineligible products, expect rejection.
  • Backend Validation Test: Tamper with coupon data, verify rejection.
  • Concurrency & Caching Test: Simulate multiple users, test caching impact.
  • Performance Test: Measure validation time under varying loads.
  • Documentation Review: Review accuracy of validation rules in documentation.
  • Error Handling Test: Introduce errors, verify graceful handling.
  • Integration Test: Validate coupons within complete checkout process.

countermeasure.name: Store coupon codes in an encrypted or hashed format to prevent unauthorized access
countermeasure.desc:
Store coupon codes in an encrypted or hashed format to prevent unauthorized access

Rationale:

Storing coupon codes in an encrypted or hashed format involves securing coupon code data by transforming it into an encrypted or hashed form before storage. This measure ensures that sensitive coupon information remains inaccessible to unauthorized individuals even if a breach occurs. By employing encryption or hashing techniques, the control safeguards coupon codes from exposure and potential misuse.

Remediation:

  • Algorithm Choice: Select encryption (e.g., AES) or secure hash (e.g., SHA-256).
  • Key or Salt Generation: Generate encryption keys or hashing salts.
  • Encryption or Hashing: Apply chosen method to coupon codes.
  • Key Management: Secure keys or salts with proper measures.
  • Database Update: Modify database schema for encrypted or hashed storage.
  • Insertion: Encrypt or hash coupon codes on insertion.
  • Access Control: Restrict access to coupon code data.
  • Monitoring: Implement intrusion detection and monitoring.
  • Testing: Validate creation, retrieval, and verification.
  • Documentation: Document methods and procedures.

Impact:

Implementing the practice of storing coupon codes in an encrypted or hashed format can potentially impact performance, particularly in terms of database operations and computational overhead.

test.steps:
• Encryption Test: Create and decrypt a coupon code.
  • Hashing Test: Insert and verify a hashed coupon code.
  • Access Control Test: Attempt unauthorized coupon code access.
  • Key Management Test: Simulate key exposure and verify protection.
  • Database Performance Test: Measure insert and retrieval times.
  • Decryption/Verification Performance Test: Measure retrieval processing time.
  • Concurrency Test: Simulate high user loads on access.
  • Backup and Restore Test: Verify backup data security.
  • Monitoring Test: Trigger alerts with unauthorized access attempts.

countermeasure.name: Use cryptographically secure randomization algorithms for code generation
countermeasure.desc:
Use cryptographically secure randomization algorithms for code generation

Rationale:

Using cryptographically secure randomization algorithms involves employing robust cryptographic techniques to generate codes with high unpredictability and randomness. This control ensures that generated codes are resistant to prediction or manipulation, enhancing their reliability and security.

Remediation:

  • Algorithm Selection: Choose a trusted cryptographically secure randomization algorithm.
  • Code Generation Function: Develop a function using the chosen algorithm for code creation.
  • Length and Complexity: Determine code length and complexity.
  • Secure Storage and Distribution: Store and distribute codes securely.
  • Testing and Validation: Verify randomness and code uniqueness.
  • Monitoring: Implement anomaly detection for code generation.
  • Updates and Documentation: Stay updated on algorithms and document procedures.

Impact:

Implementing secure randomization algorithms can have an impact on performance, especially when generating a large number of codes.

reference.name: NIST SP 800-90A Recommendation for Random Number Generation Using Deterministic Random Bit Generators

test.steps:
• Algorithm Verification: Confirm use of reputable cryptographically secure algorithm.
  • Code Generation & Randomness Test: Generate codes, assess randomness and distribution.
  • Length and Security Test: Check codes' length, complexity, and secure handling.
  • Uniqueness Verification: Generate and validate unique codes.
  • Performance Impact Assessment: Measure code generation speed under different loads.
  • Entropy Gathering & Seeding Test: Evaluate entropy gathering and seeding impact.
  • Concurrency Test: Simulate multiple code generation requests.
  • Monitoring and Anomaly Detection: Test monitoring for unusual code generation patterns.

countermeasure.name: Use prepared statements for all database queries
countermeasure.desc:
Database injection attacks, such as SQLi (SQL Injection) rely on sending tainted client-side data which is used in dynamic SQL queries on the server-side in an unsafe manner. Creating queries by concatenating strings using untrusted data may result in vulnerable code; for example, an attacker appending an 'OR' statement to the customerName parameter in order to bypass checks and retrieve additional data from the database:

                       

  • String query = "SELECT user FROM users WHERE name = '"

 + request.getParameter("customerName")+"'";

The use of prepared statements with carefully controlled and validated input conditions mitigates SQLi and related attacks.

  • Database queries should always be executed using prepared statements or parameterized queries.
  • Queries through an Object-Relational mapper should also be treated as tainted input, and again executed using prepared statements to mitigate the threat.

reference.name: OSA SI-01 System And Information Integrity Policy And Procedures
OSA SI-10 Information Accuracy, Completeness, Validity, And Authenticity

test.steps:
For inputs receiving data that is subsequently added to - or used - in an SQL query:

  1. Ensure SQL meta-characters are identified and properly escaped or encoded.
  2. Data should be used in the form of parameterized SQL queries, rather than dynamically generated queries.

To test data validation:

  1. Review the code processing potentially tainted user input to SQL queries and confirm the data is executed only in pre-prepared parameterized SQL queries.
  2. Review the acceptable input criteria, and build test cases that deviate from it (invalid characters, lengths, ranges etc.)
  3. Pass invalid input to the application and review error trapping and handling.
  4. Where unexpected exceptions occur, the application may be vulnerable to attack.

countermeasure.desc:

For example, while hidden form fields, cookies or other headers may be obfuscated from a user, along with parameters passed in ViewStates or other encapsulated forms. These can be modified by the user on the client-side in memory, or in transit on the network. Similarly, data passed from binary or compiled components can be modified in situ or in transit. Furthermore, encryption only secures the data in transit between the two ends of the encrypted tunnel (one of which is typically controlled by the client); data passing through the link may still be malicious.

As an example of business rule logic, "boat" may be syntactically valid because it only contains alphanumeric characters, but it is not valid if the input is only expected to contain colors such as "red" or "blue." 
  • Implement a 'known good' or white-list approach, where only inputs that meet the strict criteria for each input are accepted, and reject, transform, or encapsulate any non-compliant data.

OSA SI-10 Information Accuracy, Completeness, Validity, And Authenticity

Identify data input points for the application, for example: 

  • Forms with user input (including hidden fields)
  • API calls
  • HTTP Headers
  • Application states such as ASP Viewstates
  • Serialized Java objects
  • Any data structure received from the client-side
  • For every input, define accepted input (both syntactic and semantic criteria)
  • Where possible, define a white-list of accepted input or characters
  • For each of the inputs, ensure that the data is validated against the defined whitelists (for example with a regular expression) before being processed.

A number of tools can be used to aid in testing:

  • Directly from your browser with the Developer Tools.
  • Using a browser extension which allows you to modify the request and responses on the fly (i.e. Tamper Data).
  • Using a proxy which allows you to modify the request and response on the fly (i.e. OWASP ZAP, Burp, Fiddler, etc.).

threat.name: Sensitive data is compromised through unauthorized access to data
threat.desc:
Attackers can gain access to sensitive data when the data is in transit in clear text, or when the data is stored without encryption.
Attackers who gain access to unencrypted data can easily read and extract the information, potentially leading to identity theft, financial fraud, and other serious security breaches. In addition, compliance requirements and data protection regulations may require the use of encryption to protect sensitive data, and failure to do so may result in penalties and legal liabilities.

threat.name: Attackers cause denial of service, disclose sensitive information or execute arbitrary code by XML manipulation
threat.desc: Simple Object Access Protocol (SOAP) is used as a communication protocol between a client and server to invoke web services on the server. It is an XML-based protocol, and therefore suffers from many of the same shortcomings as other XML-based protocols. Miscreants can potentially leverage these shortcomings to mount an denial of service attack, disclose sensitive information and execute arbitrary code. This may be attempted via SOAP parameter tampering, in which an attacker sends a SOAP message in which the field values are other than that which the server is likely to expect, in order to precipitate non-standard server behavior.

threat.name: Attackers gain access to user data by manipulating server-side code
threat.desc: Server-Side Code Injection happens when an attacker is able to direct input under his control and mix it with executed code on the server-side by modifying the logic executed on it.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorised access to the application through buffer overflow flaws
threat.desc: Buffer Overflow attacks target improper or missing bounds checking on buffer operations, typically triggered by input injected by an attacker. As a consequence, an attacker is able to write past the boundaries of allocated buffer regions in memory, causing a program crash or potentially redirection of execution as per the attackers' choice.

threat.name: An attacker exploits a weakness in the configuration of access controls and is able to bypass the intended protection that these measures guard against and thereby obtain unauthorized access to the application
threat.desc: An Access Control functionality often spans many areas of software depending on the complexity of the access control system. For example, managing access control metadata or building caching for scalability purposes are often additional components in an access control system that need to be built or managed. Vulnerabilities appear when a user is able to successfully request access to something they usually shouldn't have access to. Oftentimes this is found when the authorization is not implemented properly. A typical example would be a certain endpoint on a website that throws a 403 forbidden error which is then bypassed by adding an X-Forwarded-For: "127.0.0.1" header.

weakness.name: There is not a recover or backup mechanism
weakness.desc: There are not any processes or mechanisms to regularly save the data to another place in order to have an older version of the data to restore in case of loss. Consequently the data cannot be easily recovered or they cannot be recovered at all.

weakness.name: Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm
weakness.desc: The use of a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm is an unnecessary risk that may result in the exposure of sensitive information.

reference.name: CWE-327: Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm

weakness.name: Use of Single-factor Authentication
weakness.desc: The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme.

countermeasure.name: Use MFA for Payment Gateway
countermeasure.desc:
Use MFA for Payment Gateway

Rationale:
Multi-factor authentication (MFA) adds an extra layer of security to the authentication process by requiring the user to provide two or more forms of identification. This helps to prevent unauthorized access to the payment gateway by ensuring that only authorized individuals are able to log in.

Remediation:
Implement MFA for sensitive actions such as account creation, changes to account details, and processing payments. This can include using a combination of something the user knows (such as a password), something the user has (such as a mobile device or security token), and something the user is (such as a fingerprint or facial recognition).

Impact:
None

test.steps:
1. Test the newly implemented MFA on different devices and browsers to ensure compatibility
2. Test the recovery process for forgotten or lost MFA device or credentials
3. Test the MFA on different scenarios, such as account creation, changes to account details, and processing payments
4. Test the MFA with multiple users to ensure scalability

countermeasure.name: Use of SSL/TLS encryption for Payment Gateway
countermeasure.desc:
Use of SSL/TLS encryption for Payment Gateway

Rationale:
SSL (Secure Sockets Layer) and its successor, TLS (Transport Layer Security), are cryptographic protocols that provide secure communication over the internet. They are used to establish an encrypted link between a web server and a client, such as a web browser, ensuring that all data exchanged between the two parties is private and secure.

Remediation:
Implement SSL/TLS encryption for all communication between the payment gateway and clients. This can be done by installing a valid SSL/TLS certificate on the payment gateway web server and configuring the server to use SSL/TLS for all communication.

Impact:
Implementing SSL/TLS encryption may have a slight impact on the performance of the payment gateway, as additional processing power is required to encrypt and decrypt the data.

test.steps:
1. Verify that the SSL/TLS certificate is valid and has not expired
2. Verify that the certificate is properly installed on the server and configured to be used for all communication
3. Test the payment gateway using a web browser and verify that the SSL/TLS encryption is being used by checking for the padlock icon and "https" in the URL
4. Test the payment gateway using a tool like SSL Labs [SSL Labs|https://www.ssllabs.com/] to check for any vulnerabilities or misconfigurations.

countermeasure.name: Use regular backups for Payment Gateway
countermeasure.desc:
Use regular backups for Payment Gateway

Rationale:
Regular backups of all transaction data is a critical step in ensuring that information can be restored in case of a security breach, or other system failure. Without regular backups, there is a risk that data may be permanently lost, making it difficult or impossible to recover from an incident.

Remediation:
Implement a regular backup schedule for all transaction data, including credit card information, and store the backups in a secure location. This can be accomplished through the use of automated backup software or manual processes, as long as the backups are performed on a regular basis.

Impact:
Implementing regular backups can have a positive impact on the security of the payment gateway, but it can also increase the amount of storage required and may require additional resources to manage. Regular backups may also result in a minor decrease in performance of the payment gateway.

test.steps:
1. Confirm that the backup schedule is properly configured and is running as intended.
2. Perform regular test restores of the backups to ensure that they are complete and that the data can be restored correctly.
3. Evaluate the storage requirements and the management of the backups.
4. Monitor the performance of the payment gateway after the implementation of the backups.

threat.name: Anonymous users could gain access to sensitive data
threat.desc: Attackers could access data for which they are not authorized by connecting directly to the resource, without authenticating. E.g.: GET /userdetails?ID=145 to gain direct access to that user's personal information.

threat.name: Data is intentionally or accidentally deleted
threat.desc: Data can be deleted intentionally or accidentally and cannot be recovered. Attackers could rely on the lack of backup and recovery mechanisms.

threat.name: Attackers could gain access to sensitive data through a man in the middle attack
threat.desc: This type of attack targets the communication between two components (typically client and server). The attacker places himself in the communication channel between the two components. Whenever one component attempts to communicate with the other (data flow, authentication challenges, etc.), the data first goes to the attacker, who has the opportunity to observe or alter it, and it is then passed to the other component as if it were never intercepted. This interposition is transparent leaving the two compromised components unaware of the potential corruption or leakage of their communications. The potential for Man-in-the-Middle attacks yields an implicit lack of trust in communication or identity between two components.

weakness.name: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges
weakness.desc:
The software performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.
New weaknesses can be exposed because running with extra privileges, such as root or Administrator, can disable the normal security checks being performed by the operating system or surrounding environment. Other pre-existing weaknesses can turn into security vulnerabilities if they occur while operating at raised privileges. Privilege management functions can behave in some less-than-obvious ways, and they have different quirks on different platforms. These inconsistencies are particularly pronounced if you are transitioning from one non-root user to another. Signal handlers and spawned processes run at the privilege of the owning process, so if a process is running as root when a signal fires or a sub-process is executed, the signal handler or sub-process will operate with root privileges.

weakness.name: Improper Access Control
weakness.desc: The software does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: Missing Authentication for Critical Function
weakness.desc: The software does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data
weakness.desc:
• Weak encryption algorithms 
  • Loss of encryption keys 
  • Compromised encryption keys 
  • Revoked keys are still active (bad key lifecycle management)

countermeasure.name: Access the data store from an account with the least privileges necessary
countermeasure.desc: Use an account with only the minimum set of permissions required to access the data store. The account should not be able to perform operations that are not explicitly required by the component that performs these operations. For example, if a web application needs to read data from certain tables and insert and update data from others, then a database account with only those specific permissions should be used by the application server.

test.steps:
• Identify the user account used by external components to access this data store.
  • Check which permissions are assigned to this user account.
  • Verify that they are the minimum set of permissions necessary and no unnecessary permissions are assigned.

countermeasure.name: Apply required security patches to the service
countermeasure.desc:
Vendors and other maintainers of software release patches in response to security flaws and other bugs in their products.  The longer a system is exposed with a known security vulnerability, the easier to compromise it.  As the exploit enters the public domain, they get included in automated exploitation suites like Metasploit and a wider less skilled miscreant is able to leverage them.   

  • Apply patches and other software updates in a timely manner to prevent unexpected failures or exploitation.
  • Clearly define an approach for testing and applying patches, in particular security patches, with expected timescales.  There is often a small window between the release of a patch, and potentially malicious actors reverse-engineering the patch to identify and exploit the flaw.
  • Use a threat intelligence, vulnerability scanning, or other alerting services to ensure the project team is promptly aware of issues within the project or its components.

reference.name: OSA CM-01 Configuration Management Policy And Procedures

test.steps:
1. Check with the software or service vendor whether security vulnerabilities and their associated patches are available for the version deployed.
  2. Evaluate the criticality of the vulnerability and schedule a fix accordingly.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt personal data
countermeasure.desc:
Implement encryption at rest (see guidance below) or give a risk-based explanation as to why encryption was not implemented.

Use well-known encryption libraries, taking into account the data use, and do not invent your own.
  • personal data must be encrypted
  • data that is not used by the application (e.g. passwords, ...) should be hashed so they cannot be recovered easily

test.steps:
1. Verify that users' personal data processed by the application is encrypted at rest (e.g. databases).
  2. If encryption is not being leveraged, verify that there is documentation outlining the reasoning for that decision.

countermeasure.name: Require authentication before presenting restricted data
countermeasure.desc:
